title: Literary Analysis — Discovering Theme in Fiction
description: Students learn to identify and articulate the theme of a literary work by distinguishing theme from topic and tracing how authors develop themes through character actions, conflict, and resolution. They practice writing theme statements using evidence from familiar texts.
instructions:
1. Define theme as the central message or lesson an author conveys through a story.
2. Distinguish between topic (a single word like 'courage') and theme (a complete statement like 'True courage means standing up for what is right even when you are afraid').
3. Read a short story excerpt and model identifying the theme.
4. Discuss how authors develop theme through character choices, conflicts, and outcomes.
5. Introduce the formula: Topic + What the author says about it = Theme.
6. Practice identifying themes in familiar picture books or fables.
7. Model writing a theme statement with textual evidence.
8. Students read a new passage and identify the theme independently.
9. Peer-share theme statements and discuss differences in interpretation.
10. Reflect on how themes connect to real-life experiences.

slides.heading: Literary Analysis — Discovering Theme
slides.subheading: What Is the Author Really Trying to Say?

slides.setup_instructions: Print short story excerpts at appropriate reading level. Prepare the theme vs. topic chart showing examples of each. Distribute graphic organizers.

slides.text: Theme is NOT the topic or subject of a story. The topic of 'Charlotte's Web' might be 'friendship,' but the theme is 'True friendship means selflessly helping others, even at great personal cost.' Theme is always a complete statement — a message the author wants you to carry with you after the book ends.

To find the theme, ask yourself three questions: (1) What challenges does the main character face? (2) How does the character change or grow? (3) What lesson does the character — or the reader — learn by the end? The answers to these questions point directly to the theme.

Use the Theme Formula: TOPIC + WHAT THE AUTHOR SAYS ABOUT IT = THEME. For example, Topic: 'Honesty.' What the author says: 'Characters who lie face bigger problems, while honest characters earn trust.' Theme: 'Honesty, even when difficult, builds trust and prevents greater consequences.'

A strong theme statement must be supported by EVIDENCE from the text. When you state a theme, you must point to specific character actions, dialogue, or events that prove it. Use the sentence frame: 'The theme of this story is [statement] because [evidence from the text].'

slides.prompt: Read the new passage provided. (1) Identify the topic in one word. (2) Note three pieces of evidence: a character action, a line of dialogue, and a plot event that point to the theme. (3) Write a complete theme statement using the Theme Formula. (4) Write a paragraph explaining the theme using your three pieces of evidence. (5) Share with a partner — did you identify the same theme? Discuss why different readers might find different themes in the same text.

slides.text: Every story has something to teach us, but the author rarely states the theme directly — you have to discover it through careful reading. This skill of finding deeper meaning will help you in every book you read. Next lesson, we will explore symbolism — objects and images that carry meaning beyond their literal definition.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student distinguish between topic and theme, use the Theme Formula to write a complete theme statement, and support it with textual evidence?

parent_notes: Theme identification is one of the most important literary analysis skills your child will develop. It moves reading from surface-level comprehension to deeper critical thinking. At home, after reading together or watching a movie, ask 'What was the message?' to practice. It is perfectly normal for readers to identify different themes in the same text — this is a sign of thoughtful analysis, not error. Encourage your child to always back up their theme with specific evidence from the text.

title: Coordinate Graphing — Navigating the Coordinate Plane
description: Students learn the structure of the coordinate plane, including the x-axis, y-axis, origin, and four quadrants. They practice plotting ordered pairs in all four quadrants and reading coordinates from plotted points on a graph.
instructions:
1. Introduce the coordinate plane as a system for locating points using two numbers.
2. Label the parts: x-axis (horizontal), y-axis (vertical), origin (0,0).
3. Explain ordered pairs: (x, y) — x tells horizontal position, y tells vertical position.
4. Model plotting points in Quadrant I (positive, positive).
5. Introduce negative numbers on the axes and the four quadrants.
6. Model plotting points in all four quadrants.
7. Practice reading coordinates from points already plotted on a graph.
8. Play 'Coordinate Battleship' to reinforce plotting skills.
9. Connect to real-world applications: maps, GPS, game design.
10. Reflect on strategies for avoiding common mistakes (switching x and y).

slides.heading: Coordinate Graphing
slides.subheading: Navigating the Coordinate Plane

slides.setup_instructions: Display the large coordinate plane poster. Distribute 4-quadrant graph paper, colored pencils, and rulers. Prepare Battleship game boards with coordinate grids.

slides.text: The coordinate plane is like a map with two number lines that cross at the ORIGIN (0,0). The horizontal line is the X-AXIS and the vertical line is the Y-AXIS. Together, they create a grid where every point has a unique address called an ORDERED PAIR: (x, y).

To plot the point (3, 5): start at the origin, move 3 units RIGHT along the x-axis, then 5 units UP along the y-axis. Mark the point. Remember: 'Run before you jump' — x comes first (horizontal), then y (vertical). Switching them gives you the wrong location.

The axes divide the plane into four QUADRANTS. Quadrant I: (+, +) upper right. Quadrant II: (-, +) upper left. Quadrant III: (-, -) lower left. Quadrant IV: (+, -) lower right. Negative x means move LEFT; negative y means move DOWN.

Practice reading coordinates FROM a graph: find a plotted point, trace straight down to the x-axis to read the x-coordinate, then trace straight across to the y-axis to read the y-coordinate. Write the pair as (x, y). Check: does the quadrant match the signs of your coordinates?

slides.prompt: Part 1: Plot these 10 points on your graph paper and connect them in order to reveal a hidden picture: (2,3), (5,6), (8,3), (7,0), (5,1), (3,0), (2,3), (-2,3), (-5,6), (-2,3). Part 2: Play Coordinate Battleship with a partner. Each player secretly places 5 ships on their grid, then takes turns calling coordinates to find and sink them. Record all guesses as ordered pairs.

slides.text: The coordinate plane is a powerful tool used in science, engineering, video game design, and GPS navigation. Every point on Earth has coordinates (latitude and longitude) that work on the same principle. Tomorrow, we will use the coordinate plane to create and read graphs of real data.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student plot ordered pairs accurately in all four quadrants and read coordinates from plotted points on a graph?

parent_notes: Coordinate graphing is a foundational skill for algebra, geometry, and data analysis. The 'run before you jump' mnemonic (x first, then y) helps prevent the most common error of switching coordinates. At home, you can reinforce this skill with map reading, discussing latitude and longitude, or playing coordinate-based games. If your child struggles with negative numbers on the axes, review the number line concept first — the coordinate plane is simply two number lines crossing at zero.

title: The Road to World War I — Causes and Alliances
description: Students explore the complex web of causes that led to World War I, including militarism, alliances, imperialism, and nationalism (MAIN). They examine how the assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand triggered a chain reaction of alliance obligations that plunged Europe into war.
instructions:
1. Introduce World War I as the first global conflict of the modern era (1914-1918).
2. Define and discuss the four MAIN causes: Militarism, Alliances, Imperialism, Nationalism.
3. Explain militarism: the arms race and glorification of military power.
4. Map the two alliance systems: Triple Alliance (Germany, Austria-Hungary, Italy) and Triple Entente (France, Russia, Britain).
5. Discuss imperialism: competition for colonies and resources.
6. Explain nationalism: pride in one's nation that led to rivalries and desire for independence.
7. Narrate the assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand in Sarajevo, June 28, 1914.
8. Trace the chain reaction: how one event activated alliances and led to full-scale war.
9. Students create a cause-and-effect diagram showing how MAIN causes connected.
10. Discuss: Could WWI have been prevented? What would have had to change?

slides.heading: The Road to World War I
slides.subheading: Understanding the Causes and Alliances

slides.setup_instructions: Display the pre-1914 map of Europe prominently. Prepare MAIN acronym cards with definitions and examples. Print alliance diagrams showing the two systems.

slides.text: World War I (1914-1918) was called 'The Great War' because no one had seen anything like it before. Over 20 million people died. Understanding WHY it happened requires looking at four causes, remembered by the acronym MAIN: Militarism, Alliances, Imperialism, Nationalism.

MILITARISM: European nations were building massive armies and navies, trying to outdo each other. Germany and Britain competed in a naval arms race. ALLIANCES: Nations formed pacts to protect each other — if one was attacked, the others would join. This created two groups: the Triple Alliance and the Triple Entente.

IMPERIALISM: European powers competed for colonies in Africa and Asia, creating bitter rivalries. NATIONALISM: People felt intense pride in their nation and wanted independence. In the Balkans, many ethnic groups under Austria-Hungary's control wanted their own nations — this area became known as the 'Powder Keg of Europe.'

The SPARK: On June 28, 1914, Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria-Hungary was assassinated in Sarajevo by a Serbian nationalist. Austria-Hungary blamed Serbia and declared war. Russia mobilized to help Serbia. Germany backed Austria-Hungary. France and Britain joined Russia. Within weeks, most of Europe was at war — the alliance system had turned a single event into a world war.

slides.prompt: Create a cause-and-effect diagram: (1) Draw the four MAIN causes as boxes at the top. (2) Under each, write two specific examples. (3) Draw arrows showing how the assassination connected to each cause. (4) Add a timeline from June-August 1914 showing how alliances pulled nations into war one by one. (5) Write a paragraph answering: Which MAIN cause do you think was most important, and why? Could the war have been prevented?

slides.text: World War I was not caused by a single event but by decades of building tension. The alliance system meant that one spark could ignite the whole continent. Next lesson, we will examine what the war was actually like for soldiers — the reality of trench warfare.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student explain the four MAIN causes of WWI, describe the two alliance systems, and trace how the assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand triggered the war?

parent_notes: World War I is a complex topic that helps children understand how political decisions affect millions of lives. The MAIN acronym makes the causes accessible and memorable. At home, you might discuss modern alliances like NATO to show how alliance systems still operate today. The question 'Could it have been prevented?' encourages critical thinking about cause and effect in history. This lesson introduces sensitive content about war in an age-appropriate way, focusing on causes rather than graphic details.

title: Europe Before the Great War — Mapping Empires and Borders
description: Students examine the political map of Europe in 1914, identifying the major empires, nations, and colonial possessions. They compare pre-war borders to post-war borders to understand how World War I redrew the map of Europe and created new nations.
instructions:
1. Display a political map of Europe in 1914 and identify the major empires.
2. Color-code the four great empires: German, Austro-Hungarian, Russian, and Ottoman.
3. Identify smaller nations and their relationships to the empires.
4. Discuss why the Balkans were called the 'Powder Keg of Europe.'
5. Examine a post-1918 map showing new nations created after WWI.
6. Compare the two maps side by side: which empires disappeared? Which nations were created?
7. Discuss the concept of self-determination — peoples choosing their own government.
8. Identify new nations: Poland, Czechoslovakia, Yugoslavia, Finland, and the Baltic states.
9. Students create before-and-after maps showing the transformation.
10. Discuss: How does changing borders affect the people living in those regions?
materials_needed: Blank outline maps of Europe (2 per student)

slides.heading: Europe Before the Great War
slides.subheading: Mapping Empires and Borders in 1914

items: Blank outline maps of Europe (2 per student)
slides.setup_instructions: Display both the 1914 and 1919 maps where all students can see them. Distribute two blank outline maps to each student along with colored pencils and legend templates.

slides.text: In 1914, Europe looked very different from today. Four massive empires dominated: the German Empire, the Austro-Hungarian Empire, the Russian Empire, and the Ottoman Empire. These empires controlled dozens of ethnic groups who often wanted independence.

The Balkans — southeastern Europe — contained many ethnic groups under Austro-Hungarian and Ottoman control: Serbs, Croats, Bosnians, Slovenes, and more. This region was called the 'Powder Keg of Europe' because nationalist tensions were so intense that any spark could cause an explosion.

After WWI ended in 1918, three empires collapsed entirely: Austro-Hungarian, Ottoman, and Russian. The German Empire lost territory. New nations emerged based on the principle of SELF-DETERMINATION — the idea that peoples should govern themselves. Poland reappeared after 123 years of partition.

New nations created after WWI include: Poland, Czechoslovakia, Yugoslavia, Finland, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, and Austria and Hungary as separate nations. Turkey replaced the Ottoman Empire. Compare the maps: notice how many more countries exist in the 1919 map than in 1914.

slides.prompt: Create two maps: (1) On your first blank map, color-code Europe in 1914. Use different colors for each empire and independent nation. Create a legend. Label key nations and cities. (2) On your second map, color-code Europe in 1919. Highlight new nations in a bright color. (3) On the back, list all the new nations created and which empire they came from. (4) Write a short paragraph: How do you think people felt when borders changed around them?

slides.text: Maps are not just about geography — they tell stories of power, conflict, and change. The borders drawn after WWI created new nations but also new problems, as some borders divided ethnic groups or forced rivals together. These issues would contribute to World War II just twenty years later.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student identify the major empires on a 1914 map, explain which empires collapsed, and name at least four new nations created after World War I?

parent_notes: Comparing historical maps is a powerful way to understand how wars reshape the world. Your child is learning that borders are not permanent — they change based on political events. The concept of self-determination connects to democratic values your child is developing. You can extend this lesson by looking at a current map of the same region and discussing how borders have continued to change. The dissolution of Yugoslavia in the 1990s is a direct echo of the borders drawn after WWI.

title: Roll of Thunder, Hear My Cry — Chapters 1-2: The Logan Family
description: Students begin reading Mildred Taylor's Newbery Medal-winning novel set in Mississippi during the Great Depression. They meet the Logan family through Cassie's narration and explore themes of family, land ownership, and racial injustice in the 1930s South.
instructions:
1. Introduce the author Mildred Taylor and the historical setting: Mississippi, 1933.
2. Discuss what students already know about the Great Depression and segregation.
3. Read Chapter 1 aloud, pausing to discuss Cassie's voice and perspective.
4. Identify the Logan family members and their relationships.
5. Discuss the significance of land ownership for the Logan family.
6. Read Chapter 2, pausing at key moments for prediction and reaction.
7. Discuss the incident with the school bus and what it reveals about racial dynamics.
8. Examine Taylor's use of dialect and how it creates authenticity.
9. Students record character observations and predictions in reading journals.
10. Discuss: How does Cassie's perspective shape what we learn about her world?
materials_needed: Roll of Thunder, Hear My Cry by Mildred Taylor

slides.heading: Roll of Thunder, Hear My Cry
slides.subheading: Chapters 1-2: Meeting the Logan Family

items: Roll of Thunder, Hear My Cry by Mildred Taylor
slides.setup_instructions: Have copies of the novel ready. Prepare a character map organizer with spaces for name, relationship, and traits. Display the map of Mississippi and historical photographs to set the scene.

slides.text: Mildred Taylor based this novel on stories her father told about growing up in Mississippi. It is set in 1933, during the Great Depression, when the economy had collapsed and many people, especially Black families in the South, struggled to survive. The Logan family is special because they OWN their land — a rare and precious thing.

Our narrator is Cassie Logan, a nine-year-old girl who is smart, outspoken, and still learning about the racial injustice around her. Pay attention to what Cassie notices but does not fully understand — that gap between what she sees and what she knows is an important literary technique called DRAMATIC IRONY.

As we read, listen for Taylor's use of DIALECT — the way characters actually speak in rural Mississippi. This is not 'incorrect' English; it is authentic speech that brings the characters to life. Also notice the SETTING details: the red dust, the long walk to school, the weather. These are not just decoration — they reveal the characters' daily realities.

The Logan family's land is central to this story. While many Black families in 1930s Mississippi were sharecroppers working on white-owned land, the Logans own 400 acres. Think about WHY land ownership matters so much and how it affects the family's independence and dignity.

slides.prompt: In your reading journal: (1) Create a character map with each Logan family member, their role, and one key trait you noticed. (2) Write three observations about the setting — what is life like in this place and time? (3) Record the school bus incident from Chapter 2 and explain what it reveals about the racial dynamics of the community. (4) Write a prediction: What challenges do you think the Logan family will face?

slides.text: Mildred Taylor once said she wrote this book because she wanted to show a Black family that was strong, loving, and proud — not defined by suffering alone. As we continue reading, pay attention to both the injustice the Logans face AND the strength they show in response.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student identify the main characters, describe the historical setting, and explain the significance of land ownership for the Logan family?

parent_notes: Roll of Thunder, Hear My Cry is a powerful novel that deals honestly with racial injustice in 1930s America. It contains scenes depicting racism, including use of racial slurs and violence, presented through a child's perspective. The book is widely taught in upper elementary and is a Newbery Medal winner. Reading alongside your child and discussing the historical context will deepen understanding. The novel connects beautifully to history lessons about the Great Depression and civil rights. If your child has questions about the racism depicted, use them as opportunities for honest, age-appropriate conversation.

title: Symbolism in Literature — Objects That Mean More
description: Students learn to recognize and analyze symbolism in fiction, understanding how authors use concrete objects, colors, and images to represent abstract ideas. They practice identifying symbols in texts and explaining what those symbols represent with evidence.
instructions:
1. Define symbolism: when something concrete represents something abstract.
2. Share common symbols: dove = peace, red = passion or danger, light = knowledge.
3. Read a passage rich in symbolism and model identifying a symbol.
4. Discuss the difference between a symbol and a metaphor.
5. Examine how context determines what a symbol means.
6. Practice with three short excerpts containing different symbols.
7. Model writing a symbolism analysis paragraph.
8. Students identify symbols in a new passage and write analysis.
9. Discuss how symbols deepen the theme of a story.
10. Connect symbolism to the current read-aloud text.
materials_needed: Literary passages with rich symbolism (4 excerpts)
Roll of Thunder, Hear My Cry

slides.heading: Symbolism in Literature
slides.subheading: When Objects Mean More Than They Seem

items: Literary passages with rich symbolism (4 excerpts)
slides.setup_instructions: Select passages with clear symbolism appropriate for upper elementary. Prepare the reference chart and graphic organizer. Have multiple highlighter colors for color-coding symbols.

slides.text: SYMBOLISM is when an author uses a concrete object, color, or image to represent an abstract idea. A SYMBOL appears repeatedly in the story and carries meaning beyond its literal definition. For example, in many stories a locked door symbolizes secrets or barriers, and a journey symbolizes personal growth.

A symbol is different from a metaphor. A metaphor is a one-time comparison ('Life is a roller coaster'), but a SYMBOL is woven throughout the story and gains meaning each time it appears. The more a symbol shows up, the deeper its meaning becomes. Think of it as a recurring image that carries a message.

Context determines what a symbol means. Water might symbolize purification in one story but danger in another. To interpret a symbol, ask: (1) What is this object literally? (2) When does it appear — during happy or sad moments? (3) How do characters react to it? (4) What abstract idea might it represent?

A symbolism analysis paragraph follows this structure: (1) Name the symbol and what it represents. (2) Give a specific example from the text where the symbol appears. (3) Explain HOW it represents the abstract idea. (4) Connect the symbol to the theme. Example: 'The broken clock in the story symbolizes the family's fractured relationships because it appears in every scene where characters argue.'

slides.prompt: Read the provided passage carefully. (1) Highlight every object, color, or image that appears more than once. (2) Choose one recurring element and answer the four context questions from the instruction. (3) Write a symbolism analysis paragraph using the structure: name the symbol, provide textual evidence, explain the connection, and link to theme. (4) Bonus: In Roll of Thunder, Hear My Cry, what might the LAND symbolize for the Logan family? Discuss with a partner.

slides.text: Symbolism adds layers of meaning to a story. Once you learn to spot symbols, you will discover that authors are communicating much more than the surface events suggest. Great readers see both the literal story AND the deeper symbolic meaning working together.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student identify symbols in a literary text, explain what they represent using textual evidence, and connect symbolism to the broader theme?

parent_notes: Symbolism is often challenging for students because it requires abstract thinking — seeing beyond what is literally on the page. You can practice this skill anywhere: discuss symbolism in movies, artwork, or even company logos. When reading together, ask 'Do you think that object means something more than what it is?' If your child struggles, start with well-known symbols (American flag represents freedom, a heart represents love) and work toward literary examples. The connection to Roll of Thunder, Hear My Cry provides meaningful practice with a text they are currently reading.

title: Plotting Points and Reading Graphs — Real Data on the Coordinate Plane
description: Students apply coordinate graphing skills to plot real-world data and interpret graphs. They create scatter plots, read information from graphs, and begin to identify patterns and trends in plotted data, connecting graphing to scientific and social studies contexts.
instructions:
1. Review ordered pairs and the coordinate plane from the previous lesson.
2. Introduce data tables and how to convert data into ordered pairs.
3. Model plotting data from a table onto the coordinate plane.
4. Discuss appropriate scale and axis labels for real data.
5. Introduce scatter plots as a way to show relationships between two variables.
6. Model reading specific data points from a completed graph.
7. Discuss trends: Does the data go up, down, or show no pattern?
8. Practice with temperature data: plot daily high temperatures over two weeks.
9. Students create their own scatter plots from provided data sets.
10. Interpret graphs by answering questions about the data.

slides.heading: Plotting Points and Reading Graphs
slides.subheading: Real Data on the Coordinate Plane

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare three data sets: temperature over time, height vs. age, and study time vs. test score. Print data tables and graph interpretation questions. Distribute graph paper and rulers.

slides.text: Graphs turn numbers into pictures. A data table might list temperatures for each day, but a GRAPH lets you SEE patterns instantly. To create a graph from data: (1) Choose which variable goes on each axis. (2) Set an appropriate scale. (3) Label both axes with variable names and units. (4) Plot each data pair as a point.

Choosing the right SCALE is critical. If your data ranges from 50 to 90 degrees, you do not need your y-axis to start at 0. You might use a scale from 45 to 95, counting by 5s. The scale should let your data fill most of the graph — data crammed into one corner is hard to read.

A SCATTER PLOT shows the relationship between two variables. Each point represents one data pair. After plotting, look for TRENDS: if points go up from left to right, there is a positive trend (as one increases, so does the other). If points go down, there is a negative trend. If points are scattered randomly, there is no clear trend.

READING a graph is just as important as making one. To find a specific value: locate the x-value on the horizontal axis, trace up to the data point, then trace left to read the y-value. To find trends, step back and look at the overall shape. Scientists and researchers read graphs every day to draw conclusions.

slides.prompt: Create two scatter plots: (1) Plot the temperature data set — label axes, set scale, plot all points, and draw a trend line. Answer: What trend do you see? What temperature would you predict for day 15? (2) Plot the study time vs. test score data set. Answer: Is there a positive or negative trend? What does this tell you about studying? (3) Write three questions that someone could answer by reading your graphs.

slides.text: Graphs are one of the most important tools in mathematics and science. They let us see relationships that are invisible in raw numbers. The ability to both create and read graphs is a skill you will use throughout school and life — from science experiments to understanding news reports about data.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student convert data tables to scatter plots with appropriate scales and labels, identify trends in plotted data, and answer questions by reading a graph?

parent_notes: Graphing real data makes abstract math concrete and meaningful. Your child is learning to both create and interpret graphs — skills used in science, social studies, and everyday life. You can reinforce this at home by graphing anything measurable: daily temperatures, weekly allowance savings, plant growth, or exercise time. When you see graphs in newspapers or online articles, discuss them together. Ask: What are the axes? What trend do you see? What conclusions can you draw?

title: Newton's First Law — Objects at Rest and in Motion
description: Students explore Newton's First Law of Motion (inertia) through hands-on experiments and demonstrations. They learn that objects at rest stay at rest and objects in motion stay in motion unless acted upon by an unbalanced force, connecting this principle to everyday experiences.
instructions:
1. Ask: Why does a ball stop rolling? Why do passengers lurch forward when a car brakes?
2. Introduce Sir Isaac Newton and his contributions to understanding motion.
3. State Newton's First Law: An object at rest stays at rest, and an object in motion stays in motion, unless acted upon by an unbalanced force.
4. Define inertia as the tendency of objects to resist changes in motion.
5. Demonstrate inertia with the tablecloth pull (or card and coin on a cup).
6. Conduct the penny tower experiment: stack pennies and flick the bottom one.
7. Discuss friction as the force that slows and stops moving objects.
8. Students design and conduct their own inertia experiments.
9. Record observations and explain results using Newton's First Law.
10. Connect to real life: seatbelts, sports, and space travel.

slides.heading: Newton's First Law of Motion
slides.subheading: Objects at Rest and Objects in Motion

slides.setup_instructions: Set up experiment stations with materials for three demonstrations: coin-and-card trick, penny tower flick, and car-on-ramp. Have science journals ready for recording observations.

slides.text: Sir Isaac Newton (1643-1727) figured out three fundamental laws that explain how everything moves. His FIRST LAW states: An object at rest stays at rest, and an object in motion stays in motion at the same speed and direction, UNLESS acted upon by an unbalanced force. This tendency to keep doing what you are already doing is called INERTIA.

Demonstration 1 — Card and Coin: Place an index card on top of a cup. Place a coin on the card. Quickly flick the card sideways. The coin drops into the cup! Why? The coin was at REST and wanted to STAY at rest. The card moved, but the coin's inertia kept it in place. Gravity then pulled it down into the cup.

Demonstration 2 — Penny Tower: Stack 8-10 pennies in a neat tower. Use another penny to sharply strike the BOTTOM penny out of the stack. The rest of the stack should stay in place (and drop slightly). The stacked pennies were at rest and resisted the change in motion — that is inertia at work.

If objects in motion stay in motion, why does a rolling ball eventually stop? Because of FRICTION — a force between surfaces that opposes motion. Without friction (like in outer space), an object would keep moving forever. Seatbelts exist because of Newton's First Law: when a car stops suddenly, YOUR BODY wants to keep moving forward.

slides.prompt: Design your own inertia experiment: (1) Choose materials from the station. (2) Write a hypothesis: 'If I [action], then [prediction] because of inertia.' (3) Conduct the experiment three times and record observations. (4) Explain your results using Newton's First Law. (5) Draw a diagram showing the forces involved. (6) List three real-life examples of Newton's First Law (hint: think about cars, sports, and space).

slides.text: Newton's First Law explains why change requires force. Nothing changes its motion on its own — something has to push or pull it. This idea is so important that it governs everything from how planets orbit to why you wear a seatbelt. Next lesson, we will explore Newton's Second Law: what happens when a force IS applied.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student state Newton's First Law in their own words, define inertia, demonstrate it through an experiment, and give real-world examples?

parent_notes: Newton's Laws of Motion are foundational physics concepts that your child will revisit throughout their science education. The hands-on experiments make abstract concepts tangible. You can reinforce Newton's First Law at home with simple demonstrations: pull a tablecloth from under dishes (carefully!), notice how passengers lean when a car turns, or discuss why astronauts float in space. The key insight is that forces cause changes in motion — without a force, nothing changes. This connects to the broader scientific principle that every effect has a cause.

title: Impressionism — Capturing Light and Moment
description: Students explore the Impressionist art movement through the works of Monet, Renoir, and Degas. They learn how Impressionists broke from tradition by painting outdoors, using visible brushstrokes, and capturing the effects of light. Students create their own Impressionist-style painting.
instructions:
1. Introduce Impressionism as a revolutionary art movement in 1870s France.
2. Show reproductions of Monet's 'Impression, Sunrise' — the painting that named the movement.
3. Discuss how Impressionism differed from traditional art: loose brushstrokes, outdoor painting, focus on light.
4. Examine Monet's series paintings (haystacks, water lilies) showing the same subject in different light.
5. Compare Renoir's people-focused Impressionism with Monet's landscapes.
6. View Degas' dance paintings and discuss capturing movement.
7. Demonstrate Impressionist brushstroke techniques: short dabs, side-by-side colors, visible texture.
8. Students choose a subject and create an Impressionist-style painting.
9. Focus on capturing light effects rather than precise details.
10. Gallery walk to view and discuss each other's work.

slides.heading: Impressionism
slides.subheading: Capturing Light and Moment in Paint

slides.setup_instructions: Display art reproductions where all students can view them. Set up painting stations with paints, brushes, water, and paper. If weather permits, consider taking this lesson outdoors as the Impressionists would have.

slides.text: In the 1870s, a group of French artists shocked the art world. Instead of painting in dark studios with smooth, invisible brushstrokes, they went OUTSIDE and painted what they SAW — sunlight dancing on water, shadows shifting across a field, the blur of a crowd. Critics mocked them, calling their work mere 'impressions.' The name stuck, and IMPRESSIONISM was born.

Claude Monet painted the same haystacks at different times of day to show how light TRANSFORMS a subject. In morning light, the haystacks are pink and gold. At sunset, they glow orange and purple. The subject did not change — the LIGHT changed. This was Monet's revolutionary idea: the real subject of a painting is LIGHT itself.

Impressionist TECHNIQUE: Use short, quick brushstrokes instead of smooth blending. Place colors SIDE BY SIDE rather than mixing them on the palette — from a distance, your eye blends them. Use THICK paint so brushstrokes are visible. Do not outline objects — let color and light define shapes. Work QUICKLY to capture the moment.

Renoir captured the joy of people at leisure — picnics, dances, children playing. Degas painted ballet dancers, showing movement frozen in time. Each Impressionist had a unique focus, but they all shared the same goal: capture the FEELING of a moment through light and color, not photographic detail.

slides.prompt: Create an Impressionist-style painting: (1) Choose your subject — a landscape, a person, or a still life. (2) Observe how light falls on your subject: Where are the brightest spots? Where are shadows? What colors do you see in the shadows? (3) Use SHORT, VISIBLE brushstrokes. (4) Place colors side by side rather than blending smoothly. (5) Focus on capturing light and mood rather than precise details. (6) Work quickly — Impressionism is about the feeling of a moment. Title your painting and prepare to share it in the gallery walk.

slides.text: The Impressionists were rebels who changed art forever. They proved that art does not have to be photographic to be beautiful — capturing a feeling or a moment of light can be even more powerful. Your paintings today used the same techniques these revolutionary artists developed over 150 years ago.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student describe the key characteristics of Impressionism, identify works by Monet, Renoir, or Degas, and apply Impressionist techniques in their own painting?

parent_notes: Impressionism is an excellent introduction to art history because the paintings are visually accessible and the story of artistic rebellion resonates with children. Visit museum websites to explore Impressionist collections virtually — the Musee d'Orsay in Paris and the Art Institute of Chicago have extensive collections online. Encourage your child to notice how light changes throughout the day, just as Monet did. The connection between Impressionism and the science of light and color can deepen understanding of both subjects.

title: Financial Literacy — Saving vs. Spending Decisions
description: Students explore fundamental financial concepts including the difference between needs and wants, the value of saving, and how to make informed spending decisions. They practice creating a personal budget and setting savings goals using real-world scenarios.
instructions:
1. Discuss the difference between needs (essentials) and wants (extras).
2. Categorize a list of 20 items as needs or wants, discussing gray areas.
3. Introduce the concept of opportunity cost: choosing one thing means giving up another.
4. Discuss short-term vs. long-term financial goals.
5. Introduce the 50-30-20 budgeting concept: 50% needs, 30% wants, 20% savings.
6. Demonstrate how savings grow over time with a visual chart.
7. Introduce the concept of interest: earning money on saved money.
8. Students create a personal budget using a hypothetical allowance.
9. Practice making spending decisions with trade-offs.
10. Reflect: What saving goal is important to you and why?

slides.heading: Financial Literacy
slides.subheading: Making Smart Saving and Spending Decisions

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare sorting cards with 20 items ranging from obvious needs to obvious wants and some gray-area items. Print budget worksheets. Have play money available for the budgeting activity.

slides.text: Every day, people make decisions about money. The first step to being financially smart is knowing the difference between NEEDS and WANTS. Needs are things you must have to survive and function: food, shelter, clothing, healthcare. Wants are things you would LIKE to have but can live without: video games, candy, brand-name shoes.

Every spending decision involves OPPORTUNITY COST — what you give up when you choose something else. If you have $20 and spend it on a movie, the opportunity cost is the book you could have bought instead. Smart financial decisions require thinking about what you are GAINING and what you are GIVING UP.

The 50-30-20 RULE is a simple budgeting guide: spend about 50% on needs, no more than 30% on wants, and SAVE at least 20%. If you receive $10 allowance: $5 goes to needs, $3 to wants, and $2 to savings. This balance ensures you meet your needs, enjoy some wants, and build for the future.

Saved money can GROW through INTEREST. When you put money in a savings account, the bank pays you a small percentage for letting them use your money. Over time, you earn interest on your interest — this is called COMPOUND INTEREST. Even small amounts saved regularly add up significantly. A $2 weekly savings becomes over $100 in a year.

slides.prompt: Budget Challenge: You receive $50 per month. (1) List your needs and estimate their costs. (2) List your wants and estimate their costs. (3) Create a monthly budget using the 50-30-20 rule. (4) Set a savings goal: something you want that costs $75-$150. Calculate how many months of saving it will take. (5) Scenario cards: Draw three unexpected expense cards and adjust your budget. Did your savings help? (6) Write a reflection: What is one financial habit you want to start?

slides.text: Financial literacy is a life skill that will serve you forever. The habits you build now — distinguishing needs from wants, budgeting, and saving consistently — are the same habits that financially successful adults practice. Remember: it is not how much money you earn that matters most, but how wisely you manage it.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student distinguish between needs and wants, explain opportunity cost, create a basic budget using the 50-30-20 rule, and set a realistic savings goal?

parent_notes: Financial literacy is a critical life skill rarely taught formally in schools. This lesson introduces concepts your child will use for life. Reinforce at home by involving your child in age-appropriate financial decisions: comparing prices at the store, discussing family budget trade-offs, or helping them manage a real allowance using the 50-30-20 rule. If your child has savings, show them how interest works with a real bank statement. The goal is not to burden children with adult financial stress but to give them tools for smart decision-making.

title: Analyzing Theme Across Multiple Texts
description: Students deepen their understanding of theme by comparing how different authors address the same theme through different stories, characters, and settings. They practice writing comparative analysis paragraphs that reference multiple texts as evidence.
instructions:
1. Review theme identification from Day 1.
2. Read two short texts that share a common theme but different settings and characters.
3. Identify the theme in each text independently.
4. Compare: How does each author develop the same theme differently?
5. Introduce the concept of universal themes that appear across cultures and time periods.
6. Model writing a comparative theme analysis paragraph.
7. Discuss how setting and character differences affect theme presentation.
8. Students read a third text and compare its theme to the first two.
9. Write a comparative paragraph referencing at least two texts.
10. Class discussion: Why do certain themes appear again and again in literature?
materials_needed: Three short texts with related themes

slides.heading: Analyzing Theme Across Multiple Texts
slides.subheading: Same Message, Different Stories

items: Three short texts with related themes
slides.setup_instructions: Select three texts that address a common theme such as perseverance, identity, or justice but through different characters, settings, and plots. Prepare Venn diagram templates for comparing two texts.

slides.text: UNIVERSAL THEMES are messages that appear in literature across cultures, time periods, and genres. Themes like 'Good triumphs over evil,' 'True strength comes from within,' and 'Justice requires sacrifice' appear in ancient myths, modern novels, and everything in between. Authors around the world tell different stories to express the same human truths.

When comparing themes across texts, look at HOW each author develops the theme differently. One author might show perseverance through a character overcoming physical challenges, while another shows it through emotional growth. Same theme, different vehicles. The question is not just WHAT the theme is, but HOW the author communicates it.

A COMPARATIVE THEME ANALYSIS paragraph uses this structure: (1) State the shared theme. (2) Describe how Author A develops the theme (with evidence). (3) Describe how Author B develops the theme (with evidence). (4) Explain what is SIMILAR and DIFFERENT in their approaches. (5) Conclude with why this theme resonates across different stories.

Transition words for comparison are essential: 'Similarly,' 'In contrast,' 'While both authors,' 'On the other hand,' 'Like [Author A], [Author B] also.' These phrases signal to the reader that you are making connections between texts rather than just summarizing each one separately.

slides.prompt: Read all three texts and identify the shared theme. (1) Write a theme statement for each text individually. (2) Complete a Venn diagram comparing how two of the texts develop the theme. (3) Write a comparative analysis paragraph that references at least two texts, using the structure from the instruction and comparison transition words. (4) Answer: Why do you think this theme appears in so many different stories? What makes it universal?

slides.text: The fact that authors from different times and places write about the same themes tells us something important: literature reflects the shared human experience. When you can compare themes across texts, you are not just reading — you are thinking like a literary scholar.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student identify a shared theme across multiple texts, compare how different authors develop the same theme, and write a comparative analysis paragraph with textual evidence from more than one source?

parent_notes: Comparative analysis is a higher-order thinking skill that prepares your child for middle school and high school English. The ability to see connections across different texts shows sophisticated reading comprehension. At home, you can practice by comparing themes in two movies, two books, or even a book and its film adaptation. Ask: 'What message did both stories share? How did they show it differently?' This skill transfers to all subjects — comparing historical events, scientific theories, or mathematical approaches uses the same analytical thinking.

title: Coordinate Graphing — Shapes, Reflections, and Transformations
description: Students use the coordinate plane to plot vertices of geometric shapes, then explore transformations including reflections across the axes and translations. They connect algebraic coordinate rules to geometric movements on the plane.
instructions:
1. Review plotting points in all four quadrants.
2. Plot vertices of a triangle and connect them to form the shape.
3. Introduce reflections: flipping a shape across an axis.
4. Demonstrate reflecting a point across the x-axis: (x, y) becomes (x, -y).
5. Demonstrate reflecting a point across the y-axis: (x, y) becomes (-x, y).
6. Students reflect a triangle across the x-axis and y-axis.
7. Introduce translations: sliding a shape without rotating or flipping.
8. Show translation rules: adding to x moves right, adding to y moves up.
9. Students translate shapes and record the new coordinates.
10. Challenge: Combine a reflection and translation on the same shape.

slides.heading: Coordinate Graphing
slides.subheading: Shapes, Reflections, and Transformations

slides.setup_instructions: Distribute large graph paper and colored pencils. Prepare the transformation rules reference card. Have small mirrors available for students to visualize reflections on their graph paper.

slides.text: The coordinate plane is not just for plotting data points — it is a powerful tool for geometry. You can create any shape by plotting its VERTICES (corner points) and connecting them. Plot these three points and connect them: A(2,1), B(5,1), C(3,4). You have created a triangle using coordinates!

A REFLECTION is a flip across a line — like looking in a mirror. To reflect across the X-AXIS: keep the x-coordinate the same but change the sign of y. The rule is (x, y) becomes (x, -y). So point A(2,1) reflected across the x-axis becomes A'(2,-1). Place a mirror along the x-axis to verify.

To reflect across the Y-AXIS: keep the y-coordinate the same but change the sign of x. The rule is (x, y) becomes (-x, y). So point A(2,1) becomes A'(-2,1). Notice the PATTERN: reflecting across an axis means negating the coordinate that is PERPENDICULAR to that axis.

A TRANSLATION is a slide — moving every point the same distance in the same direction. The rule is written as (x + a, y + b). To translate 3 right and 2 up: add 3 to every x and 2 to every y. A(2,1) becomes A'(5,3). The shape stays the same size and orientation — it just moves to a new location.

slides.prompt: Start with rectangle ABCD: A(1,1), B(4,1), C(4,3), D(1,3). Plot it in blue. (1) REFLECT across the x-axis. Plot the new shape in red. List all new coordinates. (2) REFLECT the original across the y-axis. Plot in green. List new coordinates. (3) TRANSLATE the original 5 units left and 3 units up. Plot in purple. List new coordinates. (4) CHALLENGE: Start with any shape you design (at least 5 vertices). Perform both a reflection and a translation. Describe the combined movement.

slides.text: Transformations show how algebra and geometry connect on the coordinate plane. A simple rule like 'negate the y-coordinate' creates a perfect reflection. Video game designers, architects, and engineers use these same transformations every day. Next lesson, we will continue exploring how math and real data interact on the coordinate plane.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student plot shapes using coordinates, perform reflections across both axes, execute translations, and state the coordinate rules for each transformation?

parent_notes: Coordinate transformations bridge arithmetic and geometry, building toward algebra and more advanced mathematics. The rules are simple but powerful: changing signs creates reflections, adding numbers creates translations. If your child enjoys this, explore symmetry in nature (butterflies, snowflakes) and art (Islamic geometric patterns, M.C. Escher). Many video games and animation programs use coordinate transformations — knowing this can motivate students who are interested in technology and game design.

title: Life in the Trenches — The Reality of World War I
description: Students learn about the conditions of trench warfare during World War I, including the daily life of soldiers, the stalemate on the Western Front, and the introduction of new weapons technology. They analyze primary source letters and poems from soldiers to understand the human impact of war.
instructions:
1. Review the causes and outbreak of WWI from the previous lesson.
2. Introduce trench warfare: why it developed and how it created a stalemate.
3. Describe the structure of trench systems: front line, support, reserve, communication.
4. Discuss daily life in the trenches: mud, rats, disease, boredom, fear.
5. Introduce new weapons: machine guns, poison gas, tanks, barbed wire.
6. Read excerpts from soldier letters and poems (Wilfred Owen, adapted).
7. Discuss the concept of 'no man's land' and futile charges across it.
8. Examine statistics: the Battle of the Somme and its casualties.
9. Students write a diary entry from the perspective of a WWI soldier.
10. Discuss: How did trench warfare change people's view of war?

slides.heading: Life in the Trenches
slides.subheading: The Reality of World War I

slides.setup_instructions: Display trench diagrams and age-appropriate photographs. Pre-select soldier letters and poems that convey the experience without graphic violence. Prepare trench cross-section templates for students to label.

slides.text: When WWI began, both sides expected a quick victory. Instead, armies dug TRENCHES — long, narrow ditches stretching 400 miles from the English Channel to Switzerland. For four years, neither side could advance more than a few miles. This deadly STALEMATE defined the Western Front.

Trench systems had multiple lines: the FRONT LINE trench faced the enemy, SUPPORT trenches were behind, and RESERVE trenches held backup troops. COMMUNICATION trenches connected them. Between the opposing front lines lay NO MAN'S LAND — a devastated wasteland of craters, barbed wire, and mud that soldiers had to cross during attacks.

Life in the trenches was miserable. Soldiers stood in mud and water for days, suffered from 'trench foot' (a painful condition from constant wetness), and lived with rats and lice. New weapons made combat horrifying: MACHINE GUNS could fire 600 rounds per minute, POISON GAS caused burns and suffocation, and BARBED WIRE trapped soldiers in the open.

Soldiers wrote letters and poems that revealed the truth about war. One soldier wrote: 'We have not been dry for days. The mud is everywhere.' Poet Wilfred Owen described the horror of a gas attack. These primary sources help us understand what textbooks cannot capture — the human experience of war. Before WWI, many people glorified war. After it, very few did.

slides.prompt: Part 1: Label the trench cross-section diagram: front line, sandbags, fire step, duckboards, support trench, no man's land, barbed wire. Color-code each section. Part 2: Read two soldier letter excerpts. What emotions does each express? What details reveal daily life? Part 3: Write a diary entry (one page) from the perspective of a soldier in the trenches. Include sensory details (what you see, hear, smell, feel) and your thoughts about the war. What do you miss most about home?

slides.text: World War I shattered the idea that war is glorious. The soldiers who lived through the trenches came home changed forever. By reading their words and imagining their experiences, we honor their sacrifice and learn why peace is worth working for. Next lesson, we will study the political maps that changed as a result of this devastating conflict.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student describe trench warfare conditions, explain why a stalemate developed, identify new weapons of WWI, and analyze primary source letters or poems for historical insight?

parent_notes: This lesson addresses the reality of war in an age-appropriate way, focusing on conditions and human experiences rather than graphic violence. Primary source letters and diary writing help children develop empathy and historical thinking. Some children may find this content distressing; reassure them that studying difficult history helps us work toward a more peaceful world. The soldier diary entry activity builds both historical understanding and creative writing skills. If your child wants to learn more, Scholastic and National Geographic offer age-appropriate WWI resources.

title: The Western Front — Mapping the Stalemate of WWI
description: Students map the Western Front of World War I, tracing the trench lines from Belgium to Switzerland. They analyze how geography influenced military strategy, examine key battle locations, and understand why the front barely moved for four years despite massive loss of life.
instructions:
1. Review the concept of the Western Front stalemate from the history lesson.
2. Display a detailed map of the Western Front and identify the trench line.
3. Discuss how geography shaped the front: rivers, hills, forests, and coastline.
4. Locate key battles: Verdun, the Somme, Ypres, Marne.
5. Discuss why armies could not break through: machine guns, trenches, and barbed wire.
6. Examine how the Eastern Front differed geographically and strategically.
7. Trace the small territorial changes over four years of fighting.
8. Students create detailed maps of the Western Front with battle locations.
9. Add a timeline overlay showing when each major battle occurred.
10. Discuss: How did geography make this war so different from previous wars?
materials_needed: Blank map of France and Belgium

slides.heading: The Western Front
slides.subheading: Mapping the Stalemate of World War I

items: Blank map of France and Belgium
slides.setup_instructions: Display a large Western Front map with trench lines visible. Prepare blank maps of France and Belgium with country borders and major rivers marked. Create battle reference cards with name, date, and significance.

slides.text: The WESTERN FRONT stretched approximately 400 miles from the North Sea coast of Belgium, through northeastern France, all the way to the Swiss border. This line of trenches barely moved more than 10 miles in either direction for four years, despite battles that killed hundreds of thousands of soldiers.

Geography played a crucial role. The flat plains of Flanders (Belgium) became mud-filled swamps when shelled. The Somme River valley provided natural defensive positions. The Meuse Heights near Verdun gave the French a geographic advantage. Armies used rivers, hills, and forests as natural barriers alongside their man-made trenches.

Key battles tell the story of the stalemate. The BATTLE OF THE MARNE (1914) stopped Germany's advance on Paris. The BATTLE OF VERDUN (1916) lasted 10 months with nearly a million casualties. The BATTLE OF THE SOMME (1916) saw 20,000 British soldiers killed on the first day alone. Each battle resulted in enormous loss with minimal territory gained.

The EASTERN FRONT between Germany/Austria-Hungary and Russia was very different. The vast distances of Eastern Europe meant trench warfare was less dominant — armies could maneuver. Russia's huge territory worked both for and against it. Compare the two fronts on your map: one locked in place, the other fluid and shifting.

slides.prompt: Create a detailed map of the Western Front: (1) Draw the trench line from the Belgian coast to Switzerland. (2) Mark and label at least five major battle sites with dates. (3) Use color coding: Allied positions in blue, Central Powers in red. (4) Add geographic features that influenced the fighting: rivers, hills, forests. (5) Create a timeline strip alongside your map showing when each battle occurred. (6) On the back, write a paragraph explaining how geography contributed to the stalemate.

slides.text: The Western Front shows how geography can determine the course of a war. The terrain, combined with new weapons technology, created a stalemate that cost millions of lives for mere yards of territory. Understanding this geography helps us understand why World War I was so devastating and why it changed warfare forever.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student accurately map the Western Front, locate major battles, explain how geographic features influenced military strategy, and describe why the stalemate occurred?

parent_notes: Mapping military history develops geographic literacy and spatial reasoning while deepening historical understanding. Your child is learning to see how physical geography shapes human events — a connection that applies throughout history. If your child is interested, documentaries about WWI battles are available from PBS and the BBC that show the terrain today compared to 1914-1918. The contrast between the Eastern and Western Fronts teaches comparative geographic analysis.

title: Roll of Thunder, Hear My Cry — Chapters 3-4: Injustice and Resistance
description: Students continue reading Mildred Taylor's novel, encountering the burning of the Berry family and the degrading textbook incident at school. They analyze how Cassie begins to understand the systematic nature of racial injustice and how her family models dignified resistance.
instructions:
1. Review events from Chapters 1-2 and update the character map.
2. Read Chapter 3, pausing to discuss the night men and the Berry burning.
3. Discuss how Taylor presents violence through a child's perspective — what Cassie knows vs. what the reader understands.
4. Read Chapter 4 and the textbook incident — receiving used, damaged books labeled for Black students.
5. Analyze Mama's response: covering the inside front covers of the textbooks.
6. Discuss acts of resistance: small, everyday ways people fight injustice.
7. Examine how the children's reactions differ based on age and temperament.
8. Identify emerging symbols: the land, the road, the weather.
9. Students update reading journals with character development notes.
10. Predict: How will the Logan family respond to increasing threats?
materials_needed: Roll of Thunder, Hear My Cry by Mildred Taylor

slides.heading: Roll of Thunder, Hear My Cry
slides.subheading: Chapters 3-4: Injustice and Resistance

items: Roll of Thunder, Hear My Cry by Mildred Taylor
slides.setup_instructions: Have the novel ready at Chapter 3. Prepare discussion question cards for key moments. Have students retrieve their character maps and reading journals from the first session.

slides.text: In Chapter 3, we learn about the night men who burned Mr. Berry and his nephews. Notice how Taylor tells us this through WHISPERED CONVERSATIONS and FRAGMENTS that Cassie overhears. This technique mirrors how children often learn about adult dangers — in pieces, without full understanding. As readers, we understand more than Cassie does.

Chapter 4 brings the textbook incident: the school receives used books discarded by the white school, with a chart inside showing they were passed down after being rated 'poor' condition and assigned to 'nigra' students. Little Man's outrage and Mama's quiet act of covering the charts are both forms of RESISTANCE — one loud, one strategic.

Resistance takes many forms. Some resistance is dramatic and public. Other resistance is quiet and personal — like Mama pasting paper over insulting labels. Both are courageous. Taylor shows us that dignity can be maintained even under oppressive systems. Watch for more examples of resistance as we continue reading.

Begin tracking SYMBOLS in the novel. The LAND represents independence and security — the Logans' 400 acres give them power that sharecropping families lack. The RED DUST ROAD is a daily reminder of hardship. THUNDER and storms may symbolize the coming conflict. Record each symbol and what you think it represents.

slides.prompt: In your reading journal: (1) Update your character map — add new characters and note how existing characters are developing. (2) Compare Little Man's reaction to the textbooks with Mama's reaction. What does each response reveal about their character? (3) Start a symbolism tracking sheet: list at least two symbols you have noticed, where they appear, and what they might represent. (4) Write a response: What forms of resistance have you seen so far in the novel? Which do you think is more effective — loud protest or quiet defiance? Why?

slides.text: Taylor shows us that injustice is not just one terrible event — it is a daily reality built into systems like school textbooks and road access. The Logan family's responses teach us that resistance can be both fierce and strategic. As we continue reading, watch how the tension builds and how each family member finds their own way to fight back.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student describe the key events of Chapters 3-4, analyze different forms of resistance shown in the text, and begin tracking symbolic elements in the novel?

parent_notes: These chapters contain disturbing content including racially motivated violence (the Berry burning, described indirectly) and institutionalized racism (the textbook incident). Taylor handles these topics through a child's limited perspective, which can prompt important discussions. The textbook incident is especially powerful because it shows how racism was embedded in everyday systems, not just dramatic events. If your child is upset by the content, acknowledge their feelings and discuss how studying injustice helps us recognize and fight it today.

title: Writing with Symbolism — Crafting Meaningful Fiction
description: Students apply their understanding of theme and symbolism to their own creative writing. They plan and draft a short story that uses at least one recurring symbol to reinforce the theme, demonstrating mastery of literary analysis concepts through original composition.
instructions:
1. Review the literary analysis skills learned this week: theme and symbolism.
2. Discuss how authors plan symbols before writing — symbols are intentional choices.
3. Brainstorm themes students care about: fairness, growing up, belonging, courage.
4. Model planning a short story: choose a theme, then select a symbol to reinforce it.
5. Demonstrate how to weave a symbol throughout a story naturally.
6. Students plan their stories using a story planning graphic organizer.
7. Draft the opening paragraph, establishing the symbol early.
8. Continue drafting, including the symbol at key moments.
9. Peer feedback: Can readers identify the symbol and theme?
10. Revise based on feedback to strengthen symbolic connections.

slides.heading: Writing with Symbolism
slides.subheading: Crafting Your Own Meaningful Fiction

slides.setup_instructions: Distribute story planning organizers with sections for theme, symbol, characters, and plot. Prepare the symbol brainstorming sheet with examples of effective symbols. Have peer feedback checklists ready.

slides.text: This week you learned to FIND themes and symbols in other authors' work. Today, you become the author. You will write a short story that uses a RECURRING SYMBOL to reinforce your THEME. This is how professional authors work — they choose symbols deliberately to deepen their story's meaning.

Planning step: First, choose your THEME — a message you want readers to take away. Then choose a SYMBOL — a concrete object that represents your abstract theme. Theme: 'True friends stick together through hard times.' Symbol: a braided friendship bracelet that appears when the friends face challenges. The bracelet = their bond.

Weave your symbol NATURALLY throughout the story. Introduce it early so readers notice it. Bring it back at emotional moments — when the character faces a challenge, makes a decision, or grows. Let the symbol's meaning deepen each time it appears. By the end, the symbol should carry the full weight of your theme.

A common mistake is being too OBVIOUS with symbolism. Do not write 'The bracelet symbolized their friendship.' Instead, SHOW the character touching the bracelet when feeling lonely, or noticing it fraying when the friendship is strained. Let the reader discover the meaning — that discovery is what makes symbolism powerful.

slides.prompt: Write your symbolic short story: (1) Complete the planning organizer: theme, symbol, characters, plot outline. (2) Draft your story (aim for 2-3 pages). Include your symbol at least three times at meaningful moments. (3) Do NOT state your theme or explain your symbol directly — show, do not tell. (4) Exchange drafts with a partner. Can they identify your symbol? Can they state your theme? (5) Revise based on feedback: if your partner could not identify the symbol or theme, strengthen those elements.

slides.text: Writing with symbolism transforms you from a storyteller into a literary artist. When you plant symbols in your writing, you create layers of meaning that reward careful readers. The skills you have learned this week — identifying theme, analyzing symbolism, and now writing with both — make you a deeper reader AND a more powerful writer.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student plan and write a short story with a clear theme reinforced by a recurring symbol that appears naturally at key moments without being explicitly explained?

parent_notes: This creative writing lesson is the culmination of the week's literary analysis work. Moving from analysis to creation demonstrates true mastery. Your child is learning to think like an author, making deliberate choices about meaning and craft. When reading their story, resist the urge to point out the symbol — ask instead, 'What is the deeper meaning in your story?' Let them explain their artistic choices. This builds metacognitive awareness of their own writing process.

title: Graphing Real-World Relationships — Distance, Time, and Speed
description: Students apply coordinate graphing to represent real-world relationships between distance, time, and speed. They create and interpret line graphs that tell stories about motion, connecting mathematical graphing to scientific concepts of force and motion being studied concurrently.
instructions:
1. Review coordinate graphing with a quick plotting warm-up.
2. Introduce the concept of graphing a relationship: time on x-axis, distance on y-axis.
3. Model creating a distance-time graph for a simple scenario (walking to school).
4. Read a graph and describe the motion it represents.
5. Discuss what flat lines, steep lines, and curved lines mean on distance-time graphs.
6. Introduce the concept: the steeper the line, the faster the speed.
7. Create graphs for different scenarios: running, walking, stopping, returning.
8. Students create graphs from written scenarios and write scenarios from graphs.
9. Connect to Newton's Laws: what forces cause the changes shown in graphs?
10. Challenge: Create a graph of your own journey (real or imagined).

slides.heading: Graphing Real-World Relationships
slides.subheading: Distance, Time, and Speed on the Coordinate Plane

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare scenario cards describing different motion situations. Print graph interpretation worksheets with pre-made graphs to analyze. Distribute graph paper and rulers.

slides.text: Graphs can tell STORIES about motion. On a DISTANCE-TIME graph, the x-axis shows TIME (minutes, hours) and the y-axis shows DISTANCE from a starting point. Each point on the graph shows where you are at a specific moment. Connecting the points creates a line that tells the story of your journey.

Reading the lines: A STRAIGHT DIAGONAL LINE going up means moving at a constant speed. A FLAT HORIZONTAL LINE means STOPPED — time passes but distance does not change. A STEEP line means FAST movement (covering a lot of distance in little time). A GENTLE line means SLOW movement.

Example scenario: Maya walks to the store (5 minutes, 300 meters). She shops for 10 minutes (distance stays the same). She runs home (3 minutes, 300 meters back to 0). Plot this: the first segment slopes up gently, the middle is flat, and the last segment slopes down steeply. The graph tells Maya's story without words.

Connect to science: Newton's First Law says objects in motion stay in motion unless a force acts on them. On a graph, a CHANGE in the line (speeding up, slowing down, stopping, or turning) means a FORCE acted. When Maya stops at the store, friction and her decision (an internal force) caused the change. The graph shows physics in action.

slides.prompt: Part 1: Draw two scenario cards. Create a distance-time graph for each scenario on graph paper. Label axes, title your graph, and use a ruler for straight lines. Part 2: Look at the three pre-made graphs on your worksheet. Write a story that matches each graph — describe who is moving, how fast, when they stop, and what forces might be acting. Part 3: Create a graph of YOUR morning routine as a journey: waking up, walking to the kitchen, eating (stationary), traveling to school. Estimate times and distances.

slides.text: Distance-time graphs are used by scientists, engineers, athletes, and GPS systems every day. The ability to both create and interpret these graphs connects your math and science knowledge in powerful ways. Every line on a graph tells a story about motion — and now you can both read and write those stories.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student create distance-time graphs from written scenarios, interpret pre-made graphs to describe motion, and connect graph features to concepts of speed and force?

parent_notes: This lesson beautifully connects math and science — students are studying force and motion in science while learning to graph relationships in math. Distance-time graphs are a practical skill used in many fields. You can reinforce this at home with simple activities: time a walk to a nearby location and create a graph, or use a car trip to discuss speed and distance. If your child uses fitness trackers, they produce similar graphs. The key concept is that graphs tell stories about the physical world using the language of mathematics.

title: Newton's Second and Third Laws — Force, Mass, and Acceleration
description: Students explore Newton's Second Law (F=ma) and Third Law (action-reaction) through hands-on experiments. They investigate how force and mass affect acceleration using toy cars and ramps, and demonstrate action-reaction pairs with balloon rockets and skateboard pushes.
instructions:
1. Review Newton's First Law from the previous science lesson.
2. Introduce Newton's Second Law: Force = Mass x Acceleration (F=ma).
3. Explain the relationship: more force = more acceleration; more mass = less acceleration.
4. Demonstrate with toy cars: push the same car with different forces.
5. Demonstrate with different masses: push cars of different weights with the same force.
6. Students conduct ramp experiments measuring distance traveled.
7. Introduce Newton's Third Law: For every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction.
8. Demonstrate with balloon rockets: air pushes back, balloon pushes forward.
9. Discuss action-reaction pairs in everyday life.
10. Students design experiments demonstrating all three laws.

slides.heading: Newton's Second and Third Laws
slides.subheading: Force, Mass, Acceleration, and Action-Reaction

slides.setup_instructions: Set up ramp stations with boards and different-weight toy cars. Prepare balloon rocket supplies: tie string across the room, thread straw onto string, and have balloons and tape ready. Distribute science journals.

slides.text: Newton's SECOND LAW: Force = Mass x Acceleration (F = ma). This means: (1) The MORE FORCE you apply to an object, the MORE it accelerates. Push a cart harder, it goes faster. (2) The MORE MASS an object has, the LESS it accelerates with the same force. It is harder to push a heavy cart than a light one.

Experiment: Release a toy car from the TOP of the ramp — it travels far. Release it from the MIDDLE — it travels less. Why? Higher starting point = more gravitational force = more acceleration. Now release a HEAVY car and a LIGHT car from the same height. The light car accelerates faster because less mass means more acceleration with the same force.

Newton's THIRD LAW: For every ACTION, there is an equal and opposite REACTION. When you push against a wall, the wall pushes back on you with equal force. When a rocket expels gas downward (action), the rocket moves upward (reaction). These forces are EQUAL in strength but OPPOSITE in direction, and they act on DIFFERENT objects.

Balloon Rocket demonstration: A balloon full of air is taped to a straw on a string. When released, air rushes out the back (ACTION) and the balloon zooms forward (REACTION). This is exactly how real rockets work — they push exhaust gases backward and the rocket moves forward. Every movement you make involves action-reaction pairs.

slides.prompt: Conduct three experiments: (1) SECOND LAW — Ramp Test: Release cars from three different heights. Measure how far each travels. Record data and explain using F=ma. (2) SECOND LAW — Mass Test: Release cars of different weights from the same height. Measure distances and explain results. (3) THIRD LAW — Balloon Rocket: Build a balloon rocket on the string. Test with different balloon sizes (different amounts of air). Measure distance traveled. Explain: What is the action? What is the reaction? Draw diagrams showing forces for each experiment.

slides.text: Newton's three laws explain all motion in the universe — from a rolling ball to a launched spacecraft. The Second Law tells us how force and mass determine acceleration. The Third Law tells us that forces always come in pairs. Together with the First Law, these three principles are the foundation of all physics.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student explain Newton's Second Law using the F=ma relationship, demonstrate the Third Law with action-reaction pairs, and design experiments that test these principles?

parent_notes: Newton's Laws are among the most important concepts in science education. The hands-on experiments make abstract physics tangible and memorable. At home, you can reinforce these laws everywhere: pushing a shopping cart (Second Law — heavier cart is harder to accelerate), jumping (Third Law — you push the ground down, the ground pushes you up), or swimming (Third Law — push water backward, move forward). The balloon rocket is an especially engaging demonstration that directly parallels real rocket science.

title: Post-Impressionism — Beyond the Impression
description: Students explore how Post-Impressionist artists like Van Gogh, Cezanne, and Seurat pushed beyond Impressionism to express emotion and structure through bold colors, geometric forms, and innovative techniques. Students create artwork inspired by pointillism or expressionistic brushwork.
instructions:
1. Review Impressionism and its key characteristics from the previous art lesson.
2. Introduce Post-Impressionism as the movement that built on and went beyond Impressionism.
3. Examine Van Gogh's 'Starry Night': discuss swirling brushstrokes and emotional expression.
4. Study Seurat's 'A Sunday Afternoon' and introduce pointillism — painting with tiny dots.
5. View Cezanne's landscapes: discuss geometric shapes and structured composition.
6. Compare an Impressionist painting with a Post-Impressionist painting of a similar subject.
7. Demonstrate pointillism technique using cotton swabs or brush tips.
8. Students choose either pointillism or Van Gogh-style expressionistic brushwork.
9. Create an artwork using their chosen technique.
10. Gallery walk comparing Impressionist paintings from Day 2 with today's Post-Impressionist works.

slides.heading: Post-Impressionism
slides.subheading: Beyond the Impression — Emotion, Structure, and Innovation

slides.setup_instructions: Display reproductions of key Post-Impressionist works. Set up painting stations with two technique options: cotton swabs and paint for pointillism, or thick brushes and paint for expressionistic brushwork. Have Impressionist paintings from Day 2 available for comparison.

slides.text: The Impressionists captured LIGHT and MOMENT. But some artists wanted to go further. The POST-IMPRESSIONISTS (roughly 1885-1910) used Impressionism as a starting point but each developed a unique personal style. They wanted art to express EMOTION, show STRUCTURE, or explore the science of COLOR in ways Impressionism had not.

Vincent van Gogh painted with thick, swirling, energetic brushstrokes that seem to vibrate with emotion. Look at 'Starry Night': the sky is alive with movement. Van Gogh used color to express FEELINGS, not just to record what he saw. His yellows blaze with intensity, and his blues pulse with energy. This approach is called EXPRESSIONISM.

Georges Seurat took the opposite approach — cool, scientific, precise. He developed POINTILLISM: painting entirely with tiny dots of pure color placed side by side. From a distance, your eye blends the dots into smooth color and form. 'A Sunday Afternoon on the Island of La Grande Jatte' took two years and millions of dots to complete.

Paul Cezanne focused on the underlying GEOMETRY of nature. He saw cylinders, spheres, and cones in mountains, trees, and fruit. His structured approach influenced Cubism and all modern art. Cezanne once said, 'Treat nature by the cylinder, the sphere, the cone.' Compare his landscapes with Monet's — Cezanne shows us the BONES of the landscape.

slides.prompt: Choose your technique and create a Post-Impressionist artwork: OPTION A — POINTILLISM: Using cotton swabs dipped in paint, create a scene using only dots.
