Place different colored dots next to each other to create the illusion of blended color. Work patiently — pointillism requires precision. OPTION B — EXPRESSIONISTIC BRUSHWORK: Paint a scene using thick, bold, swirling brushstrokes in the style of Van Gogh. Exaggerate colors to express a mood (joyful yellows, moody blues, angry reds). Let your brushstrokes show energy and emotion.

slides.text: Post-Impressionism proved that art can be about more than recording what you see. It can express how you FEEL, explore the SCIENCE of perception, or reveal the hidden STRUCTURE of the world. Compare your work today with your Impressionist painting — can you see how the Post-Impressionists pushed art into new territory?
slides.mastery_check: Can the student describe the differences between Impressionism and Post-Impressionism, identify works by Van Gogh, Seurat, and Cezanne, and create artwork using either pointillism or expressionistic brushwork?

parent_notes: Post-Impressionism shows children that artistic movements build on each other — innovation happens when artists take existing ideas and push them further. Van Gogh's story of creating art despite personal struggles can inspire discussions about perseverance and self-expression. If your child chose pointillism, appreciate their patience — it is a demanding technique. If they chose Van Gogh's style, discuss how different brushstrokes create different emotional effects. Virtual museum tours of the Van Gogh Museum in Amsterdam are excellent follow-up resources.

title: Financial Literacy — Setting Goals and Making a Savings Plan
description: Students deepen their financial literacy by learning to set SMART financial goals, create a step-by-step savings plan, and understand the difference between short-term and long-term financial planning. They practice calculating how long it takes to save for goals and explore strategies for earning money responsibly.
instructions:
1. Review needs vs. wants and the 50-30-20 rule from the previous lesson.
2. Introduce SMART goals applied to finances: Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Relevant, Time-bound.
3. Model turning a vague goal ('save money') into a SMART goal ('save $60 for a new art set by saving $5 per week for 12 weeks').
4. Discuss short-term goals (weeks) vs. long-term goals (months or years).
5. Introduce the concept of tracking progress with a savings tracker chart.
6. Discuss age-appropriate ways to earn money: chores, small businesses, helping neighbors.
7. Model creating a savings plan with weekly milestones.
8. Students set their own SMART financial goal and create a plan.
9. Design a personal savings tracker.
10. Discuss: What obstacles might arise and how can you plan for them?

slides.heading: Financial Literacy
slides.subheading: Setting Goals and Making a Savings Plan

slides.setup_instructions: Print SMART goal worksheets and savings tracker templates. Have calculators available. Set up stations with poster board and markers for creating personal savings trackers.

slides.text: A goal without a plan is just a wish. SMART financial goals turn wishes into reality. SMART stands for: SPECIFIC (what exactly are you saving for?), MEASURABLE (how much money do you need?), ACHIEVABLE (can you realistically save that amount?), RELEVANT (does this goal matter to you?), TIME-BOUND (when do you want to reach it?).

Vague goal: 'I want to save money.' SMART goal: 'I will save $75 to buy a new skateboard by saving $6.25 per week from my allowance for 12 weeks.' See the difference? The SMART goal tells you exactly what to do, how much, and by when. You can track your progress and know exactly when you will reach your goal.

Short-term goals take weeks to months: saving for a book, a game, or a gift. Long-term goals take months to years: saving for a bicycle, a trip, or a college fund. Both are important. Start with a short-term goal to build confidence and habits, then add a long-term goal. Many successful savers work toward both at the same time.

A SAVINGS TRACKER makes your progress visible and keeps you motivated. It can be a chart, a thermometer that you color in, or a jar where you see money accumulating. Research shows that visualizing progress makes people more likely to reach their goals. Plan for OBSTACLES too: what if you face an unexpected expense? Build a small buffer into your plan.

slides.prompt: Create your personal financial plan: (1) Set one short-term SMART goal (4-8 weeks) and one long-term SMART goal (3-6 months). Write each using the SMART format. (2) Calculate weekly savings needed for each goal. (3) Create a savings plan showing weekly milestones. (4) Design a visual savings tracker on poster board that you can use at home. (5) List two potential obstacles and your plan to overcome each. (6) Brainstorm three age-appropriate ways you could earn extra money toward your goals.

slides.text: Financial planning is a skill that grows with you. The SMART goals and savings trackers you created today use the same principles that adults use to buy homes, start businesses, and plan for retirement. The habit of setting financial goals and saving consistently is one of the most valuable skills you can develop at any age.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student write a SMART financial goal, calculate the savings needed per week, create a step-by-step savings plan with milestones, and design a visual savings tracker?

parent_notes: This lesson turns financial concepts into actionable plans your child can implement at home. Consider helping them follow through on their SMART goal with real money — there is no better financial education than actual experience. You might match their savings to double motivation, or help them find age-appropriate earning opportunities. The savings tracker can be posted where they see it daily. Research consistently shows that children who practice money management early develop stronger financial habits as adults. The key is making the goal meaningful to THEM, not what adults think they should save for.

title: Literary Analysis Workshop — Theme and Symbolism Review
description: Students consolidate their understanding of theme and symbolism through a collaborative literary analysis workshop. They rotate through analysis stations, discuss interpretations in literature circles, and complete a culminating written analysis demonstrating mastery of both concepts.
instructions:
1. Briefly review the key concepts of the week: theme, symbolism, comparative analysis.
2. Set up four literary analysis stations with different text excerpts.
3. Station 1: Identify the theme and write a theme statement with evidence.
4. Station 2: Identify symbols and explain their meaning in context.
5. Station 3: Compare themes across two short texts.
6. Station 4: Write a creative piece using intentional symbolism.
7. Students rotate through stations in small groups.
8. Reconvene for a literature circle discussion of findings.
9. Individual culminating assessment: analyze a new passage for both theme and symbolism.
10. Share analyses and celebrate growth as literary thinkers.

slides.heading: Literary Analysis Workshop
slides.subheading: Theme and Symbolism — Putting It All Together

slides.setup_instructions: Set up four stations around the room with different text excerpts and instruction cards. Prepare analysis response sheets for each station. Have the culminating assessment passage ready for individual work.

slides.text: This week you have learned three powerful literary analysis skills: identifying THEME (the central message), analyzing SYMBOLISM (objects that carry deeper meaning), and COMPARING themes across texts. Today you will put all three skills to work in a workshop format.

Station Rotation: You will spend 8-10 minutes at each of four stations. At each station, read the text carefully, complete the analysis task on your response sheet, and discuss your thinking with your group. Remember: in literary analysis, there is often more than one valid interpretation — the key is supporting your interpretation with EVIDENCE.

Literature Circle Discussion: After stations, we will gather to share findings. Effective literature discussions follow these norms: listen actively, build on what others say, use phrases like 'I agree because...' or 'I see it differently because...,' and always refer back to the TEXT. Disagreement is welcome when it is supported by evidence.

Culminating Assessment: You will independently analyze a new passage, identifying both its theme and a key symbol. A strong analysis will: (1) State the theme as a complete sentence. (2) Identify a symbol and explain what it represents. (3) Provide at least two pieces of textual evidence. (4) Explain how the symbol reinforces the theme.

slides.prompt: Complete the station rotation (8-10 minutes per station), then participate in the literature circle discussion. Finally, complete the individual culminating analysis: Read the new passage carefully. Write a two-paragraph response that (1) identifies and explains the theme with evidence, and (2) identifies a symbol, explains its meaning, and shows how it connects to the theme. Use specific quotes or details from the text as evidence.

slides.text: You have grown significantly as literary analysts this week. You can now see beneath the surface of a story to find the deeper meaning the author has woven into the text. These skills make you not just better readers, but deeper thinkers — you look for meaning beyond the obvious in everything you encounter.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student independently identify theme and symbolism in an unfamiliar text, support interpretations with textual evidence, and explain how symbolism reinforces theme?

parent_notes: This workshop lesson assesses and celebrates the literary analysis skills your child has developed throughout the week. The station rotation format allows students to practice all skills in a collaborative setting before demonstrating mastery independently. If your child discusses the culminating assessment at home, ask them to explain their interpretation and evidence — articulating their thinking reinforces learning. Literary analysis skills transfer to all reading and critical thinking contexts, making this one of the most valuable language arts skill sets for academic success.

title: Coordinate Graphing Challenge — Mystery Pictures and Data Analysis
description: Students apply all coordinate graphing skills from the week in a culminating challenge that combines plotting accuracy, graph interpretation, and data analysis. They complete mystery coordinate pictures, analyze real-world data sets, and create their own coordinate challenges for classmates.
instructions:
1. Quick warm-up: plot five points and identify their quadrants.
2. Distribute mystery picture coordinate lists — plot all points to reveal the image.
3. Review graph interpretation skills with sample distance-time graphs.
4. Present a real-world data set and guide students through creating a graph.
5. Students interpret the graph to answer analysis questions.
6. Discuss how coordinate graphing connects to careers: data science, engineering, GPS.
7. Students create their own mystery coordinate pictures for classmates.
8. Exchange and solve mystery pictures.
9. Complete a culminating skills check covering all week's graphing concepts.
10. Reflect: How has your understanding of graphs grown this week?

slides.heading: Coordinate Graphing Challenge
slides.subheading: Mystery Pictures and Data Analysis

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare mystery picture coordinate lists with at least 20 points that reveal a recognizable image. Gather a real-world data set appropriate for scatter plotting. Print skills check worksheets.

slides.text: This week you have mastered the coordinate plane: plotting points in all four quadrants, creating scatter plots from data, performing transformations, and interpreting distance-time graphs. Today's challenge brings ALL these skills together in fun and practical applications.

Mystery Picture Challenge: You will receive a list of ordered pairs. Plot each point PRECISELY and connect them in order. Accuracy matters — one misplotted point and the picture will not look right. Check each point: Is the x-coordinate correct? Is the y-coordinate correct? Is it in the right quadrant?

Data Analysis Challenge: Real scientists, economists, and journalists use graphs to find patterns in data. You will analyze a real data set by graphing it and looking for trends. Key questions: Is there a positive, negative, or no trend? Are there any OUTLIERS (points far from the pattern)? What predictions can you make?

Creative Challenge: Design your OWN mystery picture using coordinates. First, draw a simple picture on graph paper. Then list the coordinates of each point in order. Test it by having a partner try to recreate your picture from ONLY the coordinate list. If they can recreate it accurately, your coordinates are precise.

slides.prompt: Complete three challenges: (1) MYSTERY PICTURE: Plot all points from the coordinate list accurately and reveal the hidden image. (2) DATA ANALYSIS: Graph the provided data set, identify the trend, circle any outliers, and answer the analysis questions. Make a prediction based on the trend. (3) CREATE YOUR OWN: Design a mystery picture with at least 15 coordinate points. List the coordinates in order. Exchange with a partner and solve each other's puzzles. (4) Complete the skills check covering plotting, reading graphs, transformations, and interpretation.

slides.text: Coordinate graphing is one of the most widely used mathematical tools in the world. From GPS navigation to medical imaging to video game design, the ability to locate and plot points on a plane is essential. You now have a strong foundation in this skill that will serve you in algebra, geometry, science, and beyond.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student accurately plot complex sets of ordered pairs, create and interpret scatter plots from real data, identify trends and outliers, and design coordinate-based challenges?

parent_notes: This culminating lesson assesses all coordinate graphing skills from the week through engaging challenges. The mystery picture activity makes precise plotting fun, while the data analysis component shows the real-world power of graphing. If your child creates a mystery picture at home, solving it together is a great way to practice. Coordinate graphing is directly prerequisite to algebra, which your child will encounter in middle school. Strong skills now will build confidence later. Consider exploring graphing apps or online tools that let students create digital graphs.

title: The End of World War I — Armistice and Aftermath
description: Students study how World War I ended with the armistice of November 11, 1918, and examine its aftermath including the Treaty of Versailles, the League of Nations, and the seeds of future conflict. They analyze how the war's resolution sowed the conditions for World War II.
instructions:
1. Review the course of WWI: stalemate, trench warfare, new weapons.
2. Discuss key turning points: U.S. entry in 1917 and Russia's withdrawal after revolution.
3. Describe the armistice: November 11, 1918, at 11:00 AM — the 11th hour of the 11th day of the 11th month.
4. Introduce the Treaty of Versailles and its harsh terms for Germany.
5. Discuss war guilt clause, reparations, territorial losses, and military restrictions.
6. Introduce the League of Nations — Woodrow Wilson's idea for preventing future wars.
7. Discuss why the League ultimately failed (U.S. did not join).
8. Examine the human cost: 20 million dead, a generation lost, nations destroyed.
9. Students create a Treaty of Versailles summary and evaluate its fairness.
10. Discuss: How did the treaty's terms plant seeds for future conflict?

slides.heading: The End of World War I
slides.subheading: Armistice, Treaty of Versailles, and Aftermath

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare a simplified summary of key Treaty of Versailles terms. Create a statistics chart showing casualties by nation. Have the post-war Europe map from the geography lesson available for reference.

slides.text: Two events broke the stalemate: In 1917, the UNITED STATES entered the war, bringing fresh troops and resources to the Allied side. Meanwhile, RUSSIA withdrew after revolution overthrew the Tsar. By late 1918, Germany's allies were collapsing, and Germany itself faced revolution. On November 11, 1918, at 11:00 AM, an ARMISTICE (ceasefire) ended the fighting.

The TREATY OF VERSAILLES (1919) set the terms of peace, and they were harsh on Germany: (1) WAR GUILT CLAUSE — Germany had to accept full blame for the war. (2) REPARATIONS — Germany had to pay $33 billion in damages. (3) TERRITORY — Germany lost 13% of its land and all overseas colonies. (4) MILITARY — Germany's army was limited to 100,000 soldiers.

U.S. President Woodrow Wilson proposed the LEAGUE OF NATIONS — an international organization where countries could resolve disputes peacefully instead of going to war. The League was created, but ironically, the U.S. Senate refused to join. Without American participation and enforcement power, the League could not effectively prevent aggression.

The human cost was staggering: over 20 million dead, 21 million wounded, and entire regions destroyed. An entire generation of young men was lost. The war also caused the 1918 flu pandemic, which killed 50-100 million more people. Many historians argue that the harsh Treaty of Versailles humiliated Germany and created the economic misery and resentment that allowed Adolf Hitler to rise to power.

slides.prompt: Analyze the Treaty of Versailles: (1) List the four main terms of the treaty. (2) For each term, write how it affected Germany: politically, economically, and emotionally. (3) Complete the evaluation graphic organizer: Was the treaty fair? Write arguments for BOTH sides. (4) Update your WWI timeline with key dates from 1917-1919. (5) Write a paragraph answering: How might the Treaty of Versailles have contributed to future conflict? What would you have done differently?

slides.text: World War I was supposed to be 'the war to end all wars,' but the peace that followed carried the seeds of an even more devastating conflict. The story of WWI teaches us that how we end a conflict matters as much as why we start one. Harsh peace terms can breed resentment that leads to future violence — a lesson still relevant today.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student explain how WWI ended, describe the key terms of the Treaty of Versailles, evaluate the treaty's fairness, and discuss how its terms contributed to future conflict?

parent_notes: This lesson connects the end of WWI directly to the beginning of WWII, helping your child see history as a continuous chain of cause and effect rather than isolated events. The Treaty of Versailles evaluation exercise develops critical thinking — there are legitimate arguments on both sides regarding its fairness. At home, discuss how the concept of 'fairness after conflict' applies to everyday situations: How should disagreements end? What happens when one side feels the resolution was unfair? These connections make historical thinking relevant to personal life.

title: Force and Motion Engineering Challenge — Designing for Speed
description: Students apply their knowledge of Newton's three laws to an engineering design challenge. They design, build, and test vehicles that maximize distance traveled, using scientific reasoning about force, mass, friction, and acceleration to improve their designs through iterative testing.
instructions:
1. Review all three of Newton's Laws and how they apply to vehicle design.
2. Introduce the engineering design challenge: build a vehicle that travels the farthest.
3. Discuss design considerations: mass (lighter = more acceleration), friction (smooth wheels), force (propulsion method).
4. Introduce the engineering design process: plan, build, test, improve, retest.
5. Students brainstorm designs and sketch plans with labeled forces.
6. Build vehicles using provided materials.
7. Conduct initial tests: measure distance traveled.
8. Analyze results using Newton's Laws: What forces affected performance?
9. Redesign and improve based on analysis.
10. Final competition and reflection on how science guided engineering.
materials_needed: Wheels (bottle caps, CDs, or wooden wheels)

slides.heading: Force and Motion Engineering Challenge
slides.subheading: Designing for Speed and Distance

items: Wheels (bottle caps, CDs, or wooden wheels)
slides.setup_instructions: Set up building stations with all materials accessible. Designate a smooth, long testing area (hallway or gym). Prepare measuring tape along the testing track. Have science journals ready for recording designs and data.

slides.text: Today you are ENGINEERS applying SCIENCE to solve a real problem. Your challenge: design and build a vehicle that travels the farthest distance. Every design decision connects to Newton's Laws. FIRST LAW: Your vehicle needs a force to start moving and friction will eventually stop it. SECOND LAW: Lighter vehicles accelerate more (F=ma). THIRD LAW: Balloon propulsion uses action-reaction.

Design Considerations: REDUCE FRICTION — smooth wheels that spin freely, a smooth surface between wheels and axles. REDUCE MASS — use lightweight materials; do not overbuild. MAXIMIZE FORCE — inflate the balloon fully for maximum air thrust. AERODYNAMICS — a streamlined shape reduces air resistance. Every design choice should be justified by physics.

The ENGINEERING DESIGN PROCESS: (1) DEFINE the problem. (2) BRAINSTORM solutions. (3) PLAN your best idea — sketch with labels. (4) BUILD a prototype. (5) TEST and MEASURE results. (6) ANALYZE — what worked and what did not? Use Newton's Laws to explain. (7) IMPROVE your design based on analysis. (8) RETEST. Engineers rarely succeed on the first try — iteration is the key.

Document EVERYTHING in your science journal: your initial sketch, your hypothesis (how far you predict it will travel and why), your test results, your analysis of what forces affected performance, your redesign plan, and your final results. Scientists and engineers who document their process can learn from both successes and failures.

slides.prompt: Engineering Challenge: (1) PLAN: Sketch your vehicle design. Label where each of Newton's Laws applies. Write a hypothesis. (2) BUILD: Construct your vehicle in 10 minutes. (3) TEST: Run your vehicle on the test track. Measure and record the distance. (4) ANALYZE: Why did it go that far? What forces helped? What forces hurt? (5) IMPROVE: Make ONE design change based on your analysis. (6) RETEST: Run again and compare results. Did your change help? (7) REFLECT: Write which Newton's Law was most important in your design and why.

slides.text: Engineering is applied science — you used Newton's Laws not just to understand motion, but to CONTROL it. The iterative design process shows that failure is not the opposite of success; it is a step toward it. Real engineers at NASA, Tesla, and every design firm use this same process: plan, build, test, improve, repeat.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student apply all three of Newton's Laws to a design challenge, use the engineering design process to iterate and improve, and explain their design decisions using scientific reasoning?

parent_notes: This engineering challenge is the culmination of the week's science learning, showing your child that scientific knowledge has practical applications. The iterative design process — building, testing, analyzing, improving — mirrors real engineering and develops resilience and problem-solving skills. If your child wants to continue at home, encourage them to modify their vehicle design and test different variables: different propulsion methods, different wheel types, different surfaces. The key learning is that scientific principles GUIDE engineering decisions, and that improvement comes through systematic testing, not random changes.

title: Music of the Impressionist Era — Debussy and Musical Color
description: Students explore Impressionist music through the compositions of Claude Debussy and Maurice Ravel, discovering how musicians created 'sound paintings' that paralleled visual Impressionism. They listen for musical color, atmosphere, and mood, then create their own sound compositions inspired by nature.
instructions:
1. Connect to visual Impressionism studied this week — same era, same goals, different medium.
2. Introduce Claude Debussy as the leading Impressionist composer.
3. Listen to an excerpt from 'Clair de Lune' and discuss the mood it creates.
4. Compare Debussy's flowing, atmospheric music with the structured music that came before.
5. Listen to 'La Mer' (The Sea) and discuss how music can paint a picture.
6. Introduce Ravel's 'Bolero' and discuss how repetition and dynamics create atmosphere.
7. Discuss musical elements: dynamics (loud/soft), tempo (fast/slow), tone color (instrument choices).
8. Students choose a nature scene and plan a sound composition to represent it.
9. Create compositions using instruments, voices, or found sounds.
10. Perform compositions while classmates guess the nature scene.
materials_needed: Audio recordings of Debussy and Ravel

slides.heading: Music of the Impressionist Era
slides.subheading: Debussy, Ravel, and Musical Color

items: Audio recordings of Debussy and Ravel
slides.setup_instructions: Queue audio recordings of Clair de Lune, La Mer (excerpt), and Bolero (excerpt). Set up a listening area with good speakers. Lay out instruments and found sound objects for the composition activity. Prepare nature scene cards.

slides.text: Just as Monet and Renoir captured light and atmosphere in paint, Claude DEBUSSY (1862-1918) captured mood and atmosphere in SOUND. He rejected the rigid rules of classical music and created something new: music that shimmers, floats, and paints pictures in the listener's mind. He called his approach 'musical Impressionism.'

Listen to 'Clair de Lune' (Moonlight). Close your eyes. What do you see? What do you feel? Debussy did not write a melody you can hum — he created an ATMOSPHERE. The music washes over you like moonlight. Notice how the notes flow into each other without sharp edges, just like Impressionist brushstrokes blend into each other.

Listen to an excerpt from 'La Mer' (The Sea). Debussy spent years perfecting this piece. You can HEAR the waves, the wind, the vastness of the ocean. He used DYNAMICS (loud and soft), TEMPO changes (fast and slow), and unusual instrument combinations to create the impression of the sea without literally imitating wave sounds.

MUSICAL COLOR refers to the unique sound quality of different instruments and combinations. A flute sounds airy, a cello sounds warm, drums sound percussive. Impressionist composers chose instruments like an artist chooses paint colors — each sound adds to the overall mood. When you create your composition, think about which sounds match the FEELING of your scene.

slides.prompt: Create a nature sound composition: (1) Draw a nature scene card (forest, ocean, thunderstorm, sunrise, river). (2) Plan your composition: What sounds represent your scene? What mood do you want to create? Should it be loud or soft? Fast or slow? (3) Choose 3-5 instruments or found sounds. (4) Arrange your sounds in an order that tells a story (beginning, middle, end). (5) Practice your composition with your group. (6) Perform for the class — can they guess your nature scene? (7) Discuss: How did musical choices create the atmosphere?

slides.text: Impressionism was not just a visual art movement — it transformed music too. Debussy and Ravel proved that music can paint pictures and create atmospheres just as powerfully as canvas and paint. This week, you have experienced Impressionism through both visual art and music, seeing how the same artistic philosophy can express itself in different mediums.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student describe the characteristics of Impressionist music, compare it to visual Impressionism, identify works by Debussy or Ravel, and create a sound composition that evokes a specific atmosphere?

parent_notes: Connecting visual art and music through the Impressionist movement helps children see how artistic ideas cross boundaries between mediums. Debussy's music is widely available on streaming platforms — listening at home, especially before bedtime, can be a calming and culturally enriching experience. Ask your child to describe what they see in their mind when listening. The composition activity develops creativity, collaboration, and musical thinking. If your child is interested, explore how film composers use similar techniques to create mood — movie soundtracks are modern descendants of Impressionist musical ideas.
